Award.AwardTitle: CS 10K: The Partnership for Early Engagement in Computer Science High School (PEECS-HS) Program: Exposing Students to Computer Science in Washington, DC Public Schools

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The Howard University Department of Systems and Computer Science proposes the Partnership for Early Engagement in Computer Science High School (PEECS-HS) program. This program partners Howard University with Washington, D.C. Public Schools (DCPS) and Google, Inc. to introduce a new course titled "Introduction to Computer Science (CS)" across DCPS high schools. The course will adopt and extend the Exploring Computer Science curriculum, originally piloted in the Los Angeles Unified School District (LAUSD). PEECS-HS will introduce students to the broad range of opportunities in CS, and allow them to develop basic competencies in CS fundamentals, and maintain a positive perception of CS. In addition, the program will produce a new unit on Mobile Application Development, which will be added to the general Exploring Computer Science curriculum. PEECS-HS will prepare in-service and pre-service DCPS teachers to teach the new curriculum. For sustainability, PEECS-HS will prepare in-service teachers to lead future Introduction to CS professional development sessions. As with many urban school districts, DCPS is predominately African-American, an important but often overlooked, component of the U.S. computing workforce. Many of these students exit or never enter the computing pipeline, in part because they often see CS as boring and unrelated to their interests. Introduction to CS aims to change those misperceptions. Adapting the Exploring Computer Science model to this environment will give further insight into mechanisms for attracting and retaining students from underrepresented populations in urban environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Partnership for Early Engagement in Computer Science-High School (PEECS-HS) was formed between the District of Columbia Public Schools (DCPS), Howard University Departments of Computer Science and Curriculum and Instruction, Exploring Computer Science (ECS), and Google, Inc. with a goal to broaden participation in computer science across the District of Columbia Public Schools (DCPS). Funded by a National Science Foundation CS10K grant, the PEECS-HS team at Howard University believed that leveraging an existing evidence-based curriculum grounded in inquiry, equity, and a culturally responsive content was critical to its success.

In order to meet the challenge, the primary objectives of PEECS-HS were to increase:

1. DCPS high school student exposure to computer science earlier in their academic careers to prepare them for computer science courses, undergraduate programs, and careers, and
2. the number of in-service DCPS teachers implementing the Exploring Computer Science course.  

To meet objectives 1 and 2, an agreement between each participating school was to offer the ECS as a course to 9th and 10th graders; with the ultimate goal of making ECS the first course for the CS pathway and making it a mandatory requirement for all incoming 9th grade students.  Second, the DCPS school system agreed that the professional development offered through PEECS-HS would be used to gain continuing education units. Additionally, significant time was dedicated to building a community among ECS stakeholders across the District of Columbia through formal and informal events such as: A Computer Science Education Summit, a DC K-12 CS Teacher Mixer, and a CSTA Open House to establish a DC CSTA chapter.

 Key outcomes:

1. 1,851 verified students from DCPS enrolled in the Exploring Computer Science course throughout the project period. Student participants were primarily enrolled in grades 9-12.

 2. In the 2016-2017 school year, ECS was offered at a middle school for seventh and eighth grade students.

3. A total of 70 teachers have been trained over the past four school years. The PEECS-HS project was designed to serve DCPS teachers, but many teachers from DC Public Charter Schools and DC private schools, as well as, schools outside of the District of Columbia also participated in the PEECS-HS professional development sessions.

4. 4 Graduate students who were supported by the grant and worked with the project received their Ph.D. Three students received degrees in Computer Science Education, and one in Educational Psychology. 15 undergraduate CS students were also supported by the project.

5. Additional resources to support the project (i.e. both monetary and in- kind) were obtained from additional industry participants.

6. A Mobile Apps Development Unit was created and approved by ECS organization. It is currently disseminated through the ECS community portal.

Figure 1 and 3, provides a snapshot some ECS PD activities. Figures 2 display the map of all the ECS participating schools. Figure 4 presents the total in-service teachers trained during the entire project. Figures 5 and 6, presents the total number of students impacted via the PEECS-HS program.

To meet objectives 1 and 2, an agreement between each participating school was to offer the ECS as a course to 9th and 10th graders; with the ultimate goal of making ECS the first course for the CS pathway and making it a mandatory requirement for all incoming 9th grade students. Additional resources to support the project (i.e. both monetary and in- kind) were obtained from additional industry participants. 6. A Mobile Apps Development Unit was created and approved by ECS organization. It is currently disseminated through the ECS community portal. Figure 1 and 3, provides a snapshot some ECS PD activities.
